A predator's effect on its prey species is hard to see in the short-term. However, if observed over a longer period of time, it is often apparent that predators play a role in ecosystem stability, and even play a role in the existence of the prey species in the first place. A classic example is the red-backed vole, which lives in underground colonies. Mice will destroy the nests of these rodents and so they must use other subterranean burrows or caves to find food for themselves. The cave in which they burrow allows them to live year-round in cool climate regions (Wunderle and Rowe 2006) .
Caves are ideal refuges, because they provide excellent moisture retention and temperature stability in high-moisture environments and serve as ideal habitats for subterranean invertebrates, spiders, and many small mammals. The presence of bats in caves makes the caves even safer and better refuges for these insects that are exposed to many predators.

The Armenian Genocide caused widespread emigration that led to the settlement of Armenians in various countries in the world. Armenians kept to their traditions and values in each new country. Some Armenians have made notable contributions in the fields of literature, art, dance, religion, and other social fields as well. Many Armenians today live in the United States but many are based in other countries such as Iran, Azerbaijan, Turkey and Israel. The Armenian diaspora around the world is not homogeneous. On the other hand, not all Armenians in the diaspora share the same cultural identities. For example, the American Armenians tend to be more assimilated to their host culture, while the Armenians in Israel and Turkey are more oriented towards their cultural background, and in the diaspora they generally maintain Armenian practices, including the Armenian language.

"The purpose of setting the Italian peninsula under French government is a long one. It may seem to some like a mad ambition. But I have no other choice. There is no other route out of that difficult position of France."
The campaign began on 24 October 1806 with a series of operations in the Venetian provinces. These operations quickly turned into a series of victories by the French army under the command of Marshal Louis Victor Bonaparte. These continued until 30 November, with the army encamped near Treviso, where General Jean-Baptiste Jourdan was at first forced to surrender.

Microbiological culture is a principal tool used to diagnose infectious disease. In a microbial culture, a growth medium is provided for a specific agent. In a microbial culture that does not require complex growth medium, a patient or clinical sample is exposed to a selective agent that is normally absent on the surface outside the body. The agent that the patient or clinical sample harbours is capable of entering culturing media with the assistance of a carrier and in a sufficient amount to grow the agent. The agent is isolated on an appropriate, culture medium that selectively allows the growth but not the proliferation of a closely-related microorganism. The agent is identified by an appropriate biochemical procedure, usually on the basis of morphological similarities with other growth-carrying microorganisms.

The northwestern portion of Rajasthan is generally sandy and dry. Most of this region are covered by the Thar Desert which extends into adjoining portions of UP and Madhya Pradesh. The east coast regions (Keral and Goa) comprises of limestone and coral reefs formations with vast archipelagos of little islands. The rest of Rajasthan is characterized by semi arid to desert climate conditions.
In its vast geographical landscape, Rajasthan has tremendous potential to harness solar energy resource. Rajasthan has the potential to host the maximum solar energy resources in the country, but at present, most of the installed capacity is concentrated in the western region of the state, due to the relatively higher sun exposure, high solar radiation and relatively lower costs compared to other parts of Rajasthan. A common way in which emotions are conceptualized in sociology is in terms of the multidimensional characteristics including cultural or emotional labels (e.g., anger, happiness, disgust, etc.) associated with a given emotion (Olsson, 2001 ). This is a useful approach in theory building and also a popular approach in the domain of affective computing.
From a sociological perspective, emotion, like affect (Rozckafell, 2008) and attitudes, refers to the way a person responds to a stimulus. It involves an affective component as well as a cognitive (attitudinal) component.
Attitudes do not stand in relation to a stimulus by themselves; rather, they depend on their relationship to other objects or persons. The deeper ancestral demography of Bermuda's population has been obscured by the ethnic homogenisation of the last four centuries. There is effectively no direct contact between the indigenous and settlers. The most recent major migration to the island occurred in 1838 when African slaves were first brought onto the island for economic development. There have been large waves of migration since that time, which has led to the current pattern of a highly diverse population due to the mixing of the indigenous ethnic groups. The population of Bermuda is the result of a long process of cultural and biological accretion, with a high immigration rate that has had a major impact on the identity of the Bermudian population. These historical events have led to the present complex demographic picture being very difficult to recreate using historic population history sources which tend to lack both temporal resolution and information on ethnic affiliation.

In modern particle physics, forces and the acceleration of particles are explained as a mathematical by-product of exchange of momentum-carrying gauge bosons. With this assumption, the structure of spacetime can be defined by only two quantities: four coordinates describing the spatial locations of all points on this spacetime and the spin of the particles. The spinor theory provides a framework in which this idea can be realized.
The spinor theory is based on the observation that every particle type carries two quantum numbers, called helicity and charge conjugation. This means that every particle can be identified with a vector in a four-dimensional space.
The spinor theory postulates that spacetime is constructed by a spinor field which lives in a five-dimensional space time with the metric η µν . The coordinate system is made up of six real coordinates (x µ ) representing the particle positions, three imaginary coordinates (iψ µ ) describing the particle spins and one fifth dimension corresponding to the time variable. Egocentrism in adolescents forms a self-conscious desire to feel important in their peer groups and enjoy social acceptance. Unlike the conflicting aspects of self-esteem, such as having pride and feeling humiliated, ego orientation is the desire to be a valued person at the expense of others. Furthermore, young people with this orientation want to act like their peers (Weygandt, 1989) .
Negative effects of high levels of ego orientation in adolescence, include unrealistic standards of appearance and self-esteem, a need to be superior to others, a tendency to overestimate the importance of the person's own needs, the need to fit into the group, negative feelings and a rejection of the negative aspects of real life experiences.
Individuals with a strong self-orientated orientation are more likely to experience depressive symptoms than those who are aware of their interdependence (Liebman, Greenberger, & Brody, 1993) . Negative effects include feelings of despair, isolation and hopelessness

The final major aspect of identity formation is self-esteem. Self-esteem is defined as one's thoughts and feelings about one's self-concept and identity. In addition to general self-esteem, adolescents also have a specific self-esteem pertaining to their academic and relational identity (Tajfel, 1979; Tajfel & Wilkes, 1963) or perceived self-perfectionism (Furnham & Elliot, 2013) . Adolescent individuals with higher degree of identification with academic and relational identities tend to have high self-esteem related to their academic performance and social relationships (Cialdini et al., 2007) . On the other hand, individuals with a higher level of perceived self-perfectionism tend to have lower self-esteem than low self-perfectionism individuals. As such, an increase in perceived selfperfectionism may reduce the self-esteem of young persons.

Different phases of digestion take place including: the cephalic phase , gastric phase, and intestinal phase. The cephalic phase occurs at the top of the stomach and has been shown to consist primarily of acid and pepsin without much of an effect upon the drug's pharmacologic activity. The gastric phase spans about 3 hours and is typically about 1 hour in duration. This phase can include some neutralization. A phase of neutralization occurs because of the low pH of the stomach. This neutralization occurs rapidly in the first 3 to 5 minutes after ingestion and decreases to a slower rate over the remaining time. Thus, no neutralization happens immediately but happens slowly over a period of time. It is estimated that about 20 to 35% of an oral dose is neutralized in the stomach. Communication within peer groups allows adolescents to explore their feelings and identity as well as develop and evaluate their social skills. Peer groups offer members the opportunity to have their feelings recognized and validated. Adolescents can support each other, share successes, and help each other navigate the challenges that can often accompany adolescence (Steinberg et al., 2000) . When adolescents have a sense of belonging within the peer group, these individuals are more likely to maintain positive social contacts, engage in friendships for longer periods of time, and are less likely to develop social isolation later in life (Steinberg et al., 2000) . Peer group dynamics can affect the development of self-esteem as adolescent members attempt to affirm and identify with their peers (Erikson, 1968) . The Free Movement of Workers Regulation articles 1 to 7 set out the main provisions on equal treatment of workers. First, articles 1 to 4 generally require that laws and regulations contain gender-neutral language in order to prevent the gender-specific provisions from disadvantage one sex. The requirements that the language of laws and regulations be equal to that of the Convention are also provided. Article 4 is also designed to ensure that both men and women have the same rights by prohibiting any gender discrimination among workers in the workplace, regardless of their civil status. Article 4(1) specifically prevents employers from discriminating against female labour contract workers and members of their family. Article 4(2) prevents discriminatory recruitment and employment practice; article 5 provides that the terms and conditions for employment between a private employer and a state agency (for example, in a public housing property) must be on a non-discriminatory basis. Article 6 relates to workers' rights in relation to their wage, hours of work, sick leave and maternity leave

The tentacles of cydippid ctenophores are typically fringed with tentilla ("little tentacles"), although a few species lack these elements. Each tentilla is an irregularly branching protuberance from the surface of the ctenopore. They are a major diagnostic character for genera within this genus, e.g. a single row may be characteristic of some species but two to three or more rows in others such as Carybdea verrucata or C. farreri. The tentilla are only moderately developed in Carybdea and the tentulae are only slightly developed in Helianthera, which is another genus with fringed tentacles. The polyphony of Christian a cappella music began to develop in Europe around the late 15th century, with compositions by Josquin des Prez. An important aspect of religious music, polyphony has been used in the development and application of many music theories. In music theory, polyphony describes the playing of more than one note per sound. A musical text (or melody) often is part of, although more often is outside, polyphony. A key defining feature of polyphony is that it entails the generation of melodic ideas with little or no accompanying instrumental texture. This lack of instrumental texture and simple melodic line suggests that polyphony is a musical practice appropriate for the early Christian church in which melody and chant were often performed without instruments. In theory, polyphony is also based upon a single melody, although polyphony does not require polyphony. In theory, many polyphonic arrangements can be constructed around the original melody, although any arrangement requires the melody

The landscapes of Thuringia are quite diverse. The far north is occupied by the Harz mountains, followed by the Goldene Aue, a small plateau of gently sloping hills that extends south of the Harz for several hundred kilometers. Along the southeast of this plateau is an extensive zone of low mountains known as the Taunus, which include the Taunus Bergkreis in the heart of the state’s wine-making area. On the east side of the Taunus, the landscape changes dramatically as one climbs to the Bavarian border. Along the border with Baden-Wurttemberg are hills known as the Schwarzwald; on the southern side of these are the Hunsrück. The Black Forest is dominated by a massive ridge of limestone, which rises over 500 meters above the forest floor.

In late 1203, John attempted to relieve Château Gaillard, which although besieged by Philip was guarding the eastern flank of Normandy. After besieging it for some time, John arrived with a relief force under Henry Tudor, King of England. They were able to breach Philip's defenses in the south and then defeat him in a bloody battle.

Aftermath

Philip VI of France, who now considered a conquest of England as the priority, ordered that all the castles and other strong places of the country be razed to the ground. John was to do the same with the castles of England that he had previously constructed, to prevent any further French invasion, and the castles were to be rebuilt at a new and more imposing scale.
However, upon John's death on 25 November 1204, Henry II the Younger, Duke of Normandy became aware of the king's intentions and was able to prevent his plans from coming to fruition.

Both X.25 and Frame Relay provide connection-oriented operations. But X.25 does it at the network layer of the OSI Model. Frame Relay does it at the data link layer of the OSI Model. The difference between the Frame Relay operation and the X.25 operation is that the X.25 operation does not maintain a connection because each X.25 transaction is assigned by a route to the next station down the route. Both X.25 and Frame Relay are connection-oriented. However, X.25 is a packet oriented system, whereas Frame Relay is at the data link layer of the OSI Model.
TCP provides the basic service for network applications. Frame relay also provides a connection oriented service to TCP. A frame relay link is established between two stations of a network. The area of modern Zhejiang was outside the major sphere of influence of the Shang civilization during the second millennium BC. Instead, this area was influenced by the Jie (Jia), a regional culture in which the Shang culture had little influence on the agricultural systems and in cultural style. Jie influence on the area appears to have begun in the third millennium BC and to have continued through the Bronze Age and into the Iron Age. Jie and Shang influence did not spread beyond the northern part of modern Zhejiang, and the eastern part did not enter this area in sufficient abundance to affect the development of agriculture and culture. Archaeological evidence suggests that major Zhejiang agricultural centers were largely outside the cultural influence of the Shanghai River valley until at least the first millennium BC.
The development of Zhejiang agriculture in the eastern river basin in the first millennium BC was facilitated by the development of a system of irrigation that was created by humans through many generations of agricultural development.

Settlement was particularly abundant in the Anglo-Saxon period (500–900 AD), when Anglo-Saxon tribes ruled the kingdoms around the Atlantic coasts, including most of England, Ireland and the northern areas of Wales and Scotland.
The first permanent settlements of the Anglo-Saxons in Scotland were known as "scotlandish" settlements. These settlements were usually small in size and had limited power. They comprised around 30 settlements in the Highlands, 20 in the north and 20 in the Orkneys. On 1 September 1870, the battle opened with the Army of Châlons, with 202 infantry battalions, 80 cavalry squadrons and 11 batteries of artillery. This force was driven back after one day of fighting by the French Army of the Loire under Marshal Alfred Fabvier, with his entire corps numbering only 17,000 men. This Army of the Loire's weak position left it vulnerable to a German breakthrough in the heart of France. Fabvier planned to retreat in the direction of Paris, and thus to avoid Châlons and its defenders. However, Marshal Joseph Félix Lebon, the commander of the Army of the Potomac, had arrived at the same time as Fabvier. Fabvier retreated across the northern edge of Lorraine, avoiding the battlefield altogether. Almost all ctenophores are predators – there are no vegetarians and only one genus that is partly parasitic. If food is plentiful, these pelagic animals have few concerns.
Their diet consists mainly of plankton or copepods but they also eat large krill and some small fish as well as sea urchins. If krill and fish are unavailable they will move to the deep and feed on squid, platijons and other squid.
They feed during the day inshore, while at night they drift hundreds or miles to the sea – where they will sleep for as long as there is still light.
Their mouths are large and they have fleshy skin. Many have a long proboscis-like ‘snorkel’, the most distinctive being the squid, which is almost as long as a swimming adult, and their snorkel serves the function of taking in air and also a sense of balance as they swim.

These were the women, in whose company the holy virgins might have enjoyed the heavenly nectar; women that, so long as they remained in the company of the holy virgins, they were never contaminated with the evil that was in the world and in the flesh from the very start of their existence. This same doctrine was found in the Gospel of John. In connection with Mary the holy spirit says, “ She shall conceive and bear a son, and call his name Jesus, for he will rescue his people from their sins” (John 20, 20-21). The paper's aim during each term is to keep current students informed on everything going on at Northwestern, both on campus and worldwide, and make students feel as though they belong to the Northwestern family.

The book was widely translated in Darwin's lifetime, but problems arose with translating concepts and metaphors, and some translations were biased by the translator's preconceptions about the topic. The book became especially influential in Europe, especially in France, where it was translated into German.
In later years, it became an influential text in the sciences of evolution. Its main themes are still discussed today.

Kublai's government faced financial difficulties after 1279. Wars and construction projects had drained the Mongol treasury. Efforts to raise and collect taxes had only worsened the situation, and the Mongol government was so poor that only its military leaders were paid, although in 1281 Kublai ordered that troops were to be paid regularly. In addition, Kublai had to fight the rebellious Mongols in the Central Steppe against Abaqa in 1280–81, which drained his treasury to the point that he could not provide a decent army. Despite these financial disasters, Kublai reorganized his government and military. In 1280, he created new offices, including the office of grand vizier and the office of grand eir, in which he appointed his main advisors. He also founded a new school, the Imperial Ecole, where he established the first Chinese language university, to train the next generation of Mongolian intellectuals.

In response to attribution of recent climate change, the City of Melbourne, in 2002, set a target to reduce carbon emissions to net zero by 2020. It was the first government department in Australia to commit to a target which has now been supported by nearly 100 other government departments. The City of Melbourne has been operating a project called ‘My City’, developed in consultation with local residents, which uses online data to identify areas where environmental improvement is needed. My City measures traffic flows to identify heavy goods vehicles, identifies where car parking costs money and where there are potential for improvements in areas such as public transport to help reduce the dependency on private cars. It also provides local councils with data to assist them in deciding where to best spend money. In addition, My City is working to improve transport infrastructure options in the city to help reduce transport demand and costs. The city’s recent consultation to assess the ‘green city’ vision, identifies infrastructure improvements such as public transport and cycling, to reduce environmental damage.

By 1959, American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space, because of the time needed to prepare for Mercury, then Gemini and later the Saturn V. They expected to go into orbit in 1962, but at that time, the Soviets had launched a human flight in August, 1957, and as it came close to the earth, they had to turn its direction and fly very slowly. It was in orbit until September 21, a few days after their launch, and the two crew members, Yuri Gagarin and Kriukov spent 8 hours and 55 minutes on the orbit. However, it was the Russians who decided to go first, since they had already managed to make the trip to Venus and their scientists were already studying the way to carry a man into space. Thus, on February 3, 1961, the crew of Gagarin flew into space and were in orbit for 100 minutes.

In the China of the Yuan, or Mongol era, various important developments in the arts occurred or continued in their development, including the areas of painting, calligraphy, and music, and also architecture. The major centers of excellence during this period were located in the capital and major centers like Harbin and Beijing. In the Western regions like Yunnan, Tibet, and Sichuan, there had been very little contact with other areas of China so arts were mainly developed around local customs.
In the Ming and Qing dynasties, arts and crafts found a high degree of development and many works became famous around the world. This period was particularly known for the development of Chinese calligraphy, in particular the use of brush strokes. In these time, the painting style was called the "five painting method." An important form of poetry and prose was called "Yu Xie" or "Yu."

Boundaries can be inclusive or exclusive depending on how they are perceived by other people. An exclusive boundary arises, for example, when a person adopts a position that excludes a particular set of values or opinions from her own system of values (Nisbett, 2003: 254; Turner, 2005) . Conversely, an inclusive boundary involves a person adopting a position that includes a subset of another person's values and beliefs. Thus, an individual may adopt a position that favors religion only with regard to those who share some of her own faith, whereas another individual may adopt the same position with regard to those who are non-religious. In either case, the boundary may be inclusive when it reflects the social norms of a particular culture, or exclusive when it reflects the individual's own set of norms. Some studies suggest that members of exclusive boundary categories display greater aggression (Turner, 2005) and exhibit less cooperation (Wagner et al., 1996) . Although research suggests that boundaries may be exclusive or inclusive

Predators are often another organism's prey, and likewise prey are often predators. Though blue jays prey on insects, they may in turn be predated upon by smaller birds.
The term "food web" describes the hierarchical grouping of organisms based on the interaction structure of their food webs. Food webs are often summarized in food chain diagrams, also called flow diagrams, showing the relationship between organisms in various categories (top layer of web, bottom layer of web), and showing the number of links between each pair of organisms (the size of each arrow). These diagrams provide an overview of the food web structure, its dynamics and its stability. Food webs also represent many of the relationships between organisms and environmental factors, including nutrient cycles and energy budgets.

Structure

Economists Hendrik Wolff, Howard Chong and Maximilian Auffhammer discuss the HDI from the perspective of data error in the underlying health system measurement. The authors argue that there is no clear data error for the HDI’s measurement. Instead, the current system is so flawed that it should be replaced. The HDI should, therefore, be calculated by taking into account the human costs of different diseases. However, a comprehensive health system analysis has yet to be made. If there are any deficiencies in a health system, the data on disease must include the full costs of health problems, including the costs of preventing diseases, taking care of the sick and the impact of mortality.
If a society experiences a crisis in its health system, it will then be possible to measure the health risks of the society. These health risks will then become the focus on public discussion and debate.

In response to the early-to-mid-17th century "continental rationalism" John Locke (1632–1704) proposed in An Essay Concerning Human Understanding (1690). Locke posited an ontology that is grounded in the principle that "the human mind is simply a kind of machine." In Locke's view, we are a kind of "animal thinking machine", whose capacities for reasoning, knowledge and action are entirely constituted by its brain as a machine. Because of this "animal thinking machine", Locke argues, we are all susceptible to the same sorts of intellectual blindnesses and error as human beings who are biologically incapable of reasoning. Locke concludes that "there is something very singular, both in our minds and bodies, that has caused men to imagine the possibility, that a machine could be, and act in any way, as if it were not, simply because it is so."

The system of bureaucracy created by Kublai Khan reflected various cultures in the empire, including that of the Han Chinese, Khitans, Jurchens, and Turkic Muslims from northwest China. The most important of these cultures was the Han Chinese culture, which also provided the philosophical foundation underlying Kublai Khan's system of government. Emperor Kublai was the originator of the first centralized government in the Han Chinese civilization, but Kublai Khan and his successors, especially his son Timur (Tamerlane), established a highly centralized government that was similar to, or even derived from, the preexisting state bureaucracies in China and Japan. The primary organization of the bureaucracy was a series of governmental offices linked to the Emperor, who created the governing system and organized the bureaucracy as a single institution, with a system of appointing officials, providing training for employees to improve their skills, and giving rewards for good performance.
